text: sheila's feet, the soles, were clean.  yet the kitchen floor was covered in blood, broken glass and spilled sugar, all arising from the struggle with Neville.  her long finger nails were also in perfect condition, yet she was supposed to have fought with Neville, and loaded the gun twice?   Neville was shot upstairs but not fatally.  he was marched down to the kitchen because Bamber needed him to be found next to the landline phone, to support the idea that neville made the call for help.   Bamber's last act before leaving the house was to call his own home from the phone.  then a quick cycle home and, on arriving, pick up the ringing phone to make it show that a call connected from the farm to Bamber's home.    it was a very well thought out crime but not without mistake. using the silencer was the problem.   it may have worked out had Bamber not used it, however there's a chance that in shooting the boys first, Neville and June , or Sheila, may have had the chance to call for help before Bamber could kill them, or even subdue him

text:
SO GLAD YOU COVERED THIS! Extra info: Jeremy and Sheila were adopted, and not actually blood family. June was religious to the point of of obsession. Jeremy didn‚Äôt really want to take over the family business and run the farm, he was more interested in cars, women and drinking. Sheila hated guns. The police didn‚Äôt enter the property for hours and hours as they thought they saw a curtain twitch in the farm house window, they assumed the shooter was still alive. Jeremy also called his girlfriend before he called the police, and even then he didn‚Äôt ring 999, the emergency number. He instead rung the local,police office number. 
I‚Äôve been obsessed with this case for years. Read all the books. And I still don‚Äôt know what to believe. Can‚Äôt wait to hear your thoughts. I spent my whole street in criminal justice. I specialised in working with murderers, so I would like to think I‚Äôm quite well informed. But I really really don‚Äôt know what the truth is. I lean towards the brother though.

text:
Yeah, I've been divided over this one, the 'trigger pull' seems entirely inconsequential. One could use a toe or an object. 
But if Shelia had shot herself once in the neck 1st, she'd then have to reposition the gun and chamber another round. I'm thinking going through this rotation and after the subsequent wound to the neck, the position the gun would be in, it should be pretty soaked in blood. I don't know if it was and they covered that? Doesn't sound like they covered much at all. I don't trust Jeremy's girlfriend but whose to say. The whole thing is mystifying. I thought silencers didn't work when they were cold? I know it's only a 22. Or 'two two' as we seem to say here, lol. But still indoors with the sound moderator, I'd think people, the dogs would definitely hear. It's a very strange one. Of course entirely possible he went room to room and that's how it happened. Maybe Shelia did fight back and that's the wound to the neck? It's a shame the police didn't you know, preserve the crime scene. Just an after thought. 
More of a shame this happened at all. 
I do wonder how bad a home life has to be to drive not 1 but 2 adopted children quite mad. If Jeremy did it then he's a more dangerous kind of mad then poor Shelia. But all around, so many disturbing upsetting things. Poor people.

text:
It was absolutely Jeremy. I remember the thorough news coverage at the time and there are loads of details that seem to be overlooked now.
Sheila loved her children and had no reason to kill them. She was relatively stable on her medication and not a risk to them.
Jeremy hated his family, was narcissistic and manipulative and also greedy, selfish and entitled. He wanted everything to himself.
It's pretty obvious; he killed everyone who could also inherit, knowing he could pin the blame on Sheila.
He let slip to his girlfriend information that made her suspect him. His whole demeanour was weird.
And as well as calling police, why didn't he rush there himself? How did they get there first, unless he wanted them to get there first?
He's a manipulative psychopath.

text: June was shot 7 times mostly in the head,face and neck.The key to this case is what was not found .NO gunshot residue on Sheila hands on her nightie or anywhere else on her body .Sheila had to load the magazine at least twice for her to fire 25 shots yet there was no trace of lubricant found on her hands from loading the magazine with bullets as they are coated in lubricant .during a psychotic episode she managed to fire 25 shots and  hit the target every time  even though Neville was on the move having been shot firstly in the bedroom he managed to get past Jeremy while he aimed the rifle at a screaming June .Neviile received further shots on the stairs SHE NEVER MISSED .Impossible as she had no interest in firearms and had never ever been seen firing one .The rifle used in the murders was a semi automatic meaning when you insert a loaded magazine into the rifle you must pull on a tiny lever  to  chamber a round before the rifle will fire Sheila would not have known this plus the tiny lever used to chamber rounds on that rifle was not marked.Sheila would not have a clue on how that rifle works

text:
Re your deficiencies. If you are b12 deficient then olease ask your doctor to test you MMA and/or homocystein. Bloodlevels on their own don't mean that much. It's the ability to have it taken up by your tissues that counts and the two tests I mentioned can be used to test that. Most often people who can't take up B12 need to inject themselves with it in their muscles (butt or upperleg). Sometimes docs don't allow you do it yourself but enough docs do after a short instruction which in itself is easy. You just need to get over sticking a needle in your muscle, but to me only the skinpricking part is a bit unpleasant. Don't feel the rest 
Oral supplements don't work if you have an uptake issue, even if your bloodlevels do go up. 

I am just taking a wild guess but perhaps others can be helped here too as it is still commonly believed that if you are not below a certain bloodlevel, there is no problem which I literally am proof of that that isn't true. My levels were low normal. My GPwould have told me it was fine just eat more animal products. But the lab did an extra test, I don't know if that was protocol or just someone who knew more about b12 metabolism and they testerld my MMA which was too high, meaning I had an uptakeproblem. My urologist quickly discovered the resson which can't be undone so I am now on lifelong injections. I likely already have nerveissues and glad they found out and right away put me on injections instead of giving me oral supplements that only masked the problem while destroying my body slowly irreversibly.

Sorry for the long post and you likely don't even read this anymore.

text: more info: call logs show a call between jeremy and his father around the time that jeremy claimed he was on the phone. the silencer was found weeks after the murder and wasn‚Äôt handed in to the police straight away (passed around people‚Äôs houses). police notes say two separate dates for when the silencer was handed in. when the police finally entered the house (hours after arriving) they noted two bodies downstairs and three upstairs. somewhere along the line of investigation, this was changed to one downstairs and four upstairs. some people believe sheila was the body downstairs and that she had shot herself once and then moved upstairs to finish it off (this doesn‚Äôt really make sense as the police would have heard the shot). the blood from the silencer was examined and an ENZYME was found that was said to be a match to one in Sheila‚Äôs blood, but actually the enzyme was common in animals like rabbits too - would make sense as they were a hunting family. the scratch on the mantelpiece wasn‚Äôt visible in any crime scene photos but was later discovered by the family of Bamber, which could suggest it was faked to frame him.

the thing is though, if Sheila disliked her mother so much and if Sheila was the killer, why would she shoot her dad 8 times and beat him, but only shoot her mom one time? that's what struck me as odd, because it was never once said that Sheila and her dad had a tense relationship, yet he got killed the most brutally. 
i've never heard of this case before, but i do believe, from what i heard in the video, that Jeremy was the killer. he had many motives and he'd been saying for YEARS previous that he wanted to kill his whole family for the money. 
it would seem the most likely that he'd target his dad first, because his dad was the only man in the house, so, despite his age, he would be physically the stronger and tougher opponent, compared to June, Sheila and the 2 little boys. 
also, Jeremy's dad knew how to use a gun, so he could potentially know how to disarm somebody too. 
my thoughts is that Jeremy was the killer, targeted his dad first for reasons said and others, killed his mom, because wasn't she found in the hallway? so she may have heard a scuffle going on, woke up to see what was going on, Jeremy had won and was already on his way upstairs, shot his mother at point blank range. i assume, depending on where the rooms are in the house, he killed his nephews next and then went to Sheila's room, maybe woke her up if she was already asleep, like Eleanor said, forced her to lie on the floor at the foot of her bed and shot her twice at the angle he did or it to look like she committed suicide and then placed the gun in her hands, took off the silencer, hid it and dipped etc. 
i honestly have no clue, that's just what i think and like i said, i know nothing of this case but what was said in this video, so i may not know of other facts regarding this case that would make me think different of what happened.

text: He probably did it, mainly because of it being physically impossible for her to commit suicide with that size gun. With that said, one thing that really bothers me is his dark comments to his girlfriend being used as evidence that he actually wanted them dead. My sister and I joke around a lot about the fact that if someone ever is killed and the police read our texts, we will definitely be convicted. My mother, for example, wasn't the greatest, and we've said all kinds of things about her to each other, including wanting to hit her with a frying pan, etc. And both of us have joked about wanting to kill our husbands when we were mad at them. But neither of us would ever actually harm anyone in "real life." Some people just have a really dark sense of humor - and the girlfriend may have pretended to think it was fine so long as they were together, but then thought it was relevant in this case later.

text:
Hello Eleanor,
when you mentioned this case possibly being "one of the worst miscarriages of justice that this country ever had" I was forthright reminded of the case of George Stinney Jr. He was a 14 year young African American boy, who was convicted and executed, for the murders of two young girls - Betty June Binnicker (11) and Mary Emma Thames (7) - , in a proceeding that was later vacated as an unfair trial. He was convicted, sentenced to death, and executed by electric chair in 1944, thus becoming the youngest American with an exact birth date confirmed to be sentenced to death and executed in the 20th century. It's an absolutely tragic and blatantly infuriating story.. 
(I believe the Stephen King novel "The Green Mile", which later was adapted into a movie of the same name, was based on- or at least heavily inspired by this case.)
I'd love to see you cover this case someday, if possible, especially since I feel like it doesn't get nearly enough attention. 
If you took the time to read this, thank you and have a great day/ night!! (This counts for everyone btw, not just Eleanor.)

text: ¬†@jasminenagle¬† I am not being dramatic. I have personally been affected by suicide for years. I only found out about the origins of the phrase "committed suicide" and the stigma that it holds a few years ago. I politely brought up the topic to inform other people so if they choose to they can help stop spreading so much stigma attached to suicide.
author: @fluterify

text: ¬†@fluterify¬† okey?? Definition: committed Suicide: To kill oneself; to take one's own life
author: @jasminenagle

text: ¬†@jasminenagle¬† thank you but I am well aware of the definition.
author: @fluterify

text: ¬†@fluterify¬† oh right so gay (queer) and gay (happy) have the same meaning, yeah? Just like committed (a crime) and committed (suicide)??? Babe u are being dramatic üò≠
author: @jasminenagle

text: ¬†@jasminenagle¬† you are correct there are two different definitions of gay. I am not saying that there are two different definitions of committed. What I am saying is that in most countries today suicide is no longer a crime. Therefore, by pairing committed and suicide people who are suffering with suicidal thoughts might be less likely to seek help. If you choose to say "committed suicide" that is your choice but some people may not be aware of this information so I share it so they have the choice to stop unintentionally spreading stigma attached to suicide. Please stop calling me dramatic.
author: @fluterify

text: ¬†@jasminenagle¬† and actually the definition of "committed suicide" is to have committed the crime of killing oneself. Your definition is only for suicide it ignores the committed part.

text:
Just based off of the details in this video, I believe there is reasonable doubt of this guy's guilt... I definitely don't think it was Sheila without reasonable doubt, either. Unfortunately, I believe that by police not treating the scene properly from the beginning, potentially valuable evidence was lost that could have removed that reasonable doubt for either one of the suspected siblings... Also, I've noticed in several true crime case videos recently (from several different creators) that no one talks about the PHONE RECORDS! Yes, this was the mid 80s, but they should have been able to show if dad called son at 3am-ish if they were able to show that son called police directly instead of using 999, plus, when was 999 started ... I feel like 911 here in the USA wasn't until the 90s, but I maybe wrong on that
*Edit: Googled it and to my utter amazement, 911 started in 1968! Learned something new today!

text: ¬†@niksha9608¬† hi, yeah I can tell you, I've kinda learned to just openly talk about it rather than getting upset etc. So he didn't live with us as he was 28, married and had kids and he lived in Bedfordshire, UK (we live near Newcastle in the UK, so a good 4 hours travel) and April 30th 2009, he rang my mam to say that he was coming up to surprise me and my younger brother as he'd broke up with his wife and wanted to come and stay with us for a while to work things out. Little did my mam know that he was already up our end of the country and he'd went to see some friends from school at a house party. Early hours of May 1st 2009, he got into a little bit of an argument with someone. Now I'm not going to sit here and say my brother was an angel because he wasn't, they got into an argument over weed of all things. The man he was arguing with accused my brother of stealing his stash and he never did, my brother told him to back off and just leave it, to which the other person (his name is Liam Keith Hall) proceeded to attack my brother. Now Liam was a cage fighter at the time (he's since had his fighting license revoked) and he brutally attacked my brother, punched him once in the temple and it automatically killed him, he then proceeded to jump on top of my brother's body and punch his face some more when he was already dead. He fled into the woods and it was his family that handed him into the police. I was 9 when this happened, my younger brother being 7 and he had a daughter at only 4 years old. If you want to read about it, here is one of the many news articles: https://www.chroniclelive.co.uk/news/north-east-news/fourth-man-arrested-connection-death-1453895 Thank you for taking interest in his case, I'd absolutely love one day for Eleanor to cover it üíï

text:
‚ö†Ô∏èTrigger Warning‚ö†Ô∏è
   1st this happened in a small backwoods town, I gotta explain HOW my husband ended up removing his friend & cleaning the scene of his suicide.  
  When my husband was medically discharged from the Army we moved back to his hometown. He'd always planned on being a cop & thought being an 82nd Airborne Ranger would get him on the force with no problem.  His grandmother was good friends with the police chief though & this man had watched him grow up. Gran invited him to supper the topic came up.  He told us unfortunately given that he had a medical discharge for a skull fracture & frontal lobe TBI  he wasn't going to be able to be a cop here.  
He had a hard time finding a job & eventually went to his dad's old friend & got a job as grave digger/limo driver/ cleaner. 
This being a small town & his boss a very shrewed businessman his funeral home also offered Hazmat clean-up for crime scenes & homes where the deceased had been undiscovered for awhile.  It was a very lucrative business because he was the only one locally. Nearest one was 2 hours away.  So even if he didn't perform the funeral for the deceased, the funeral home that did had to refer business to him if they didn't want to gain the reputation of being cold hearted & making their clients clean up the scene themselves. 
      
   Our police chief's son committed suicide this way. He'd gone to the graveyard & leaned up against his grandfather's very large & ornately carved headstone. Evidently he sat there awhile too smoking cigarettes & drinking Old Grandad straight from the bottle & chasing it with coke.  When he smoked all his cigarettes he took his boots off, placed the barrel of a double barrel shotgun under his chin & pulled the triggers with his big toe. 
This gun had been his grandfather's. 
 
 He left no note but it was definitely a suicide. My husband was called in to assist in working the grid pattern to ensure there was nothing left for what Chief called " Souvenirs for the Looky Loo's & f*cking delinquent bastards"
    It's a good thing he did call the guys in though because they had to build the grid 18 rows back & 15 rows on either side.

This is why every. single. scene. should be processed thoroughly and correctly. Honestly, I'm still not fully convinced but I'm very sus on Jeremy. The few things that get me though is if the mother was the main motive, why wasn't she the one shot the most? We have seen time and time again that when it's usually a crime of passion, it's overkill. You would think the mother would have been the one beat up and shot the most. 

Also, I obviously can't speak for the father but you would think he would just call emergency services if his daughter was being threatening with a gun. She's been in and out of the hospital before so it doesn't seem like they were ones to really just ignore or pretend she wasn't ill. Why call your son? 

The last thing is the father being the one separated. It seems like he was made to get out of the way because he was main threat. It would make sense that if it was one of the children they would both want him out of the way but it just seems like if it was Sheila she would still have taken out that anger on her mother. 

I'm not sure. I don't think it was anyone else but one of them but I do feel like Jeremy seems like the more likely culprit.

(For example, I have OCD and I've had intrusive thoughts about everything from merely doing something socially unacceptable to hurting people. Before I understood how OCD worked, I thought that having those thoughts meant I wanted to do those things or that I was a bad person.) Anyway, women who suffer with schizophrenia, psychosis, OCD, etc, are way more likely to be victims of violence than they are to be perpetrators.

text:
Hi Eleanor! Thanks for the video!
Some of the evidence against Jeremy  is not very solid.
Not calling 999. In the 1980s they were rolling out the emergency numbers and they weren't available every where or considered reliable.
Him going slow, I would not rush ahead of police if I heard gun shots.
But...
The silencer. That's the clincher.
He told them his dad called and that he heard gun shots. You don't "hear gun shots" with the silencer. He had to remove it. It was only there to not wake people.
It's bizarre that the little ones were killed so viciously, while Mom had 1 shot.
Did they check Shiela for SA? If he had, that would certainly explain how he shot her, under the chin, with her lying down.  
It seems someone was very angry/upset over/with Nevil and the children, but liked the Mom. Had more feelings for her. If Sheila did this, why such anger at her kids, but not Mom. I don't think Sheila did it at all. She was definitely a victim.

text:
He's guilty. It's just too convenient that he stands to inherit everything and doesn't seem too upset about his family's deaths. Also, if the father had time to make a phone call, why would he call his son if there were already gunshots? Surely he would have called 999 to give him and his family the best odds of surviving. And if the son heard the gunshots before the phone was disconnected, and the theory was that the father had been shot ... was he found anywhere near a phone? I'm assuming they were landlines being used...are there records of a call coming from the home at that hour? What about the son receiving the call? He could have easily called his own place to make it look more realistic, but if he's not there to answer it that would blow his alibi. 

If the daughter had killed everyone else, wouldn't she be covered in gunpowder residue? I suppose they didn't test initially because of the supposed suicide. But if they had, I wonder if they would have found much besides where her wounds were located.

text:
‚Äã¬†@Mercyfalls¬† 
But the only things which indicated that Sheila murdered her family was her having the gun (which is questionable how she used it to kill herself) and her brother's statement that their father rang him saying she was attacking them.
Without these two things, the police wouldn't have suspected her of murder.

author: @TheAlorra

text:
¬†@Mercyfalls¬† Exactly this.

That she didn't do it doesn't prove that he did. And given they destroyed most relevant evidence, we probably will never have the evidence needed to prove that he did without reasonable doubt, even if we believe he did it (and I think he probably did.) Especially when so much of the evidence is, "This guy over here said that he said this thing". Do we even know he said that thing? Or are people who want attention making up stuff because they believe he did it?

Keep in mind how often people confess to crimes they didn't even commit.

What we have are a few pieces of physical evidence that throw things into doubt, but they don't prove that he specifically did it.

It's better to let 10 guilty people go free than to convict one innocent person. Remember that the most important thing is to not punish the innocent. We have to be very, very careful with these things - because if we set up a standard where we punish people because we don't like them or 'it seems like they probably did it', then the same standard can be applied to us.
author: @emeryltekutsu4357

text:
¬†@Mercyfalls¬† Most juries actually take things quite seriously. Compare how things were treated in the UK in Johnny Depp's defamation case versus how it was treated in the US. In the UK, the judge was tainted and it was ridiculously bad. Not saying that's what always happens, but the professionals can absolutely fail you, and then you're going to have a lot of corruption from people who can be paid off.

Juries are harder to taint. It's random people each with their own thoughts. You don't know what random person is going to be called in, so you can't have them paid off in your back pocket.

There will always be issues, but in general, juries actually work very well. The professionals that were showing up for the Johnny Depp VS Amber Heard case were so out there that the case is literally being animated Ace Attorney style and it FITS. Professionals will find a way to say what people want them to say or fit things into their own biases.

Personally, I would 100% ask for a jury on my cases, because then I know I can get regular people who will understand where I'm coming from. That's way better than getting ground pounded by lawyer-type that speaks legalese and can twist things their own way for the big guys.
author: @emeryltekutsu4357

text:
‚Äã¬†@emeryltekutsu4357¬† I've heard that 'better to let ten guilty go free than to wrongly convict one innocent' thrown around alot but have you every stopped and truly considered the implications of it? I mean, sure...it sounds great from a moral perspective but one look at the statistical likelihood of reoffending would be enough to show its essentially a load of bs. ü§î 

Unless you are claiming ruining the life of one innocent individual (and by extension that of their close family and friends) is somehow worse than ruining the lives of ten perpertrator's worth of victims, plus the lives of their family and friends plus the lives of all the potential victims they now have opportunity to target in the future all because they were allowed to walk free?

author: @joemamalolllll7290

text:
¬†@Jadianne¬† When you say, "I don't care if innocents are put in jail", literally no one is safe anymore. That's the point. If you're willing to throw one innocent person in jail, you're willing to throw all the innocent people in jail. I'm sure that'll be fun when it's you that it happens to, and people say, "Well, whatever. Maybe we got it wrong, but at least we put SOMEONE in jail, even if it wasn't the person who actually did it!"

You DON'T put people in jail unless you know they did it. I'm perfectly fine with that system. How many cases have we discovered the WRONG person was in jail for a lifetime now? Never, never give up on protecting innocent people, because once you do it's absolute tyranny. We HAVE to have principles. And we have to realize that, even if we think something is true, if we can't prove it... maybe we're WRONG. We could be right, but we could be wrong, and that shouldn't be the standard for jailing someone for life.

I think he did it. I also have never met him and have no idea if much of what was said about him is even true. Do you know if it's all true? Were you there? Are you happy throwing people's lives away over flimsy evidence at best? If he gets away with it, it's because the police messed up big time and didn't properly investigate a giant multiple murder scene, but that doesn't mean we lower our standards for locking someone away.
author: @emeryltekutsu4357

text:
¬†@emeryltekutsu4357¬† Did you even read my comment? Do yourself a favour and get down off the soap box for a second. I don't recall saying an innocent person going to jail for a crime they did not commit is perfectly acceptable. 

In fact if the claim being made was that it is better to let 'a' guilty individual go free (as in one single) than to wrongly convict an innocent I would even agree.....since not only would you be committing an injustice against the innocent party and their family but the victims and their families never get to receive true justice because the one being 'punished' is not the actual perpertrator.

But to say something like 'yeah, it's much better to let ten guilty persons get away with murder (whether literally or figuratively) than to wrongly convict one innocent person suggests to me one of two things.....either you fail to comprehend the true extent of the devastation that occurs when the guilty go free or...and this is far worse imo.....you are actually well aware of the harm that it causes but the sanctity of the judicial system is of far more importance to you than a few lives being ruined.

¬†@beethimbles8801¬† they're the ones who profited in the end (always the first people you should suspect), plus they conveniently produced the silencer and pointed the finger at Jeremy.  There was also evidence that Sheila had only just died when police got there (one of the officers described blood still flowing from her) and nobody stood outside had heard a shot, suggesting that the silencer was on the gun when it was fired.  If I remember right there was a sequence of crime scene photos that showed the silencer on a fireplace, but the police never recovered it (this info was online, but must have got taken down due to data privacy laws a few years back when Bamber launched an appeal as I can't find it now).  I belive someone was still in the house when police arrived, it couldn't have been Jeremy as he was outside with police.

Jeremy clearly doesn't have a very nice personality and seems to lack empathy, but that doesn't automatically make him a murderer.

The police also bungled the investigation massively - evidence was lost, the crime scene wasn't managed properly - just a complete mess.  Jeremy was a convenient, easy target.

Calling the non-emergency number could be explained as a)Jeremy panicking and forgetting (people do weird things when stressed) b) him thinking a local force would know the location better and therefore get there quicker - which is reasonable in a time before sat nav and Google maps.
author: @nicolawalton3754

text: ¬†@delchia9420¬† yes and I get a feeling there was some resentment towards Jeremy and Sheila both inheriting when they were both adopted and possibly because they both seemed to have some mental health problems (in my unprofessional opinion Jeremy may have BPD; he has trouble with empathy and expressing emotion - doesn't automatically make him a murderer though).
author: @nicolawalton3754

text: ¬†@nicolawalton3754¬† I could see how you could think that about the cousins. But why would Jeremy automatically assume and say it was Sheila if his dad said ‚Äúshe has a gun‚Äù or ‚Äúthey have a gun‚Äù? I think it‚Äôs way more likely for the dad to give a name than to be all ambiguous about it. And even then yes people do weird things while stressed but be fr who forgets a 999 number that they‚Äôve probably known their whole life and searches up the local police station in a phone book? And also I don‚Äôt really think that calling the local police station is all that different than dialing 999 (rather than to stall or push time back) because even if you call 999 they would be able to get people on the way there p much immediately. And also the paint from the window was on Jeremy‚Äôs gun. How would the cousins get it from him without him knowing? And then why would he say he left it loaded at the house if that obviously wasn‚Äôt true? And Jeremy was most likely closer to the house than the police station as he was just a few miles away so why would he, a person known for driving fast, be going so slow that the police overtook him on the road?
author: @futuredisneystar2

text: ¬†@futuredisneystar2¬† it wasn't unheard of for emergency services to get lost when responding to a remote location - if I was being particularly cynical/unkind I may even hazard a guess that Jeremy might not have cared if his family got killed and may have left the gun hoping that Sheila would 'snap'.  I don't know, something just doesn't sit right with me on this case.  Sheila was still actively bleeding when she was found, despite police - and Jeremy - being stood outside the property for a while.  This means she had only just been shot - no shot was heard and the silencer wasn't nearby; it was conveniently produced at a later date ... by the cousins.   It's a weird case to try to follow as facts keep getting taken down from the internet/being put back up due to data protection laws and appeals being launched.

text:
@Bee Thimbles In the last months of her life I was introduced to Sheila by a mutual friend who was trying to help her. They told me about June's religious extremes and the damage it was having on Sheila. Our mutual friend hoped I could help Sheila with spiritual aspects and more. I only ever saw Sheila under the influence of drugs...be that medication or illegal substances I don't know. She was as spaced out while functioning that it was possible to be. She just wasn't "there" and it was so sad. She had showed me her modelling portfolio. She looked lovely in this pics of course, though they were dated at that stage. 
I was in Ireland when the news of the murders happened. My Dad was filling up the car with petrol and there was the rack of papers out the front. There was Sheila on the front pages. They had chosen a glamorous pic of her but with the horrific headline that she had killed her family, and I was...well...what...what the hell...what??? I had the phone number to her flat and trying to ring to hope to find someone to speak with but, of course it wasn't answered at that time.
It DID seem plausible she had done it, but that doesn't mean she did do it.  At the beginning I really did think she'd done it. I mean, she really was a mess and, from what I know, was not getting the support she needed. 
The facts are what matters, but with the latest interest in the tragedy I find myself going back and reviewing it all.
